G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all times relevant to this Complaint, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, in that Plaintiff seeks money damages well within this Court’s jurisdictional limits arising from a residential landlord‑tenant relationship in Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, in that Plaintiff seeks money damages well within this Court’s jurisdictional limits arising from a residential landlord‑tenant relationship in Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the Premises are located in Worcester, Worcester County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this county.

State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.
State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et.proposition: Defendant’s failure to adequately and promptly remedy the rodent infestation constitutes a failure to maintain the Premises in a condition fit for human habitation, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 CMR 410.550 (Rodent and insect infestation) and 105 CMR 410.000 provisions requiring that the owner maintain the premises free from infestation.

105 CMR 410.550.proposition: Under 105 CMR 410.550, an owner is responsible for maintaining dwelling units free from rodents where two or more units are infested or where the infestation is the result of structural or building conditions, and must take adequate measures to prevent and eliminate such infestation.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that any lessor or landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.

105 CMR 410.020.proposition: Under 105 CMR 410.020 and related provisions, the presence of rodent infestation in residential premises is a violation of the State Sanitary Code and creates conditions that may “endanger or materially impair the health or safety and well‑being of an occupant,” which is the standard referenced in G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983)
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, residential tenants are entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment both by statute (G.L. c. 186, § 14) and by common law. See, e.g., Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983).
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is about good-cause eviction from public housing and notice requirements; it does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, either under G.L. c. 186, § 14 or at common law. The word “quiet enjoyment” or any analysis of that covenant is entirely absent from the reasoning. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts residential tenants are entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment by both statute and common law.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: In Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord’s failure to take adequate action to correct serious sanitary code violations and flooding, after notice, could constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and support an award of damages for emotional distress.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord’s repeated failure, after notice, to correct unsanitary flooding conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code both breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and supports recovery of emotional distress damages. The SJC explains that interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14 includes such sanitary code–based flooding and that ‘actual and consequential damages’ under the statute encompass reasonably foreseeable emotional distress. Although the separate $10,000 quiet enjoyment award was vacated as duplicative, the opinion clearly recognizes emotional distress damages flowing from this type of quiet‑enjoyment violation.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14… Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages… The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case… Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14….”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, resulting in conditions that materially endanger or impair the health, safety, or well‑being of the tenant, can constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102‑03 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition states that failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, creating materially endangering conditions, can constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. In Doe, the quiet enjoyment analysis concerns the landlord’s failure to take measures against criminal drug activity in common areas, not failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code or code‑based physical defects. The opinion does not link sanitary‑code noncompliance to quiet enjoyment; instead, it treats sanitary code issues under the warranty of habitability and finds no breach there. Thus, Doe does not support this specific proposition, even though it recognizes serious interference with common‑area use can breach quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court explained that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where its conduct or inaction causes a substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises, even if the landlord does not intend the result.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court explicitly rejects an intent requirement for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and focuses instead on whether substantial interference naturally and probably flowed from the landlord’s conduct or inaction. It holds the landlords liable where their leasing and failure to control the lounge caused serious noise that substantially deprived tenants of quiet enjoyment, despite the landlords’ lack of intent to create those conditions. This directly matches the proposition that a landlord breaches quiet enjoyment when its conduct or inaction causes substantial interference, even without intent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Under Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and its progeny, compliance with the State Sanitary Code is a basic obligation of residential landlords, and violations of the Code can support tenant remedies including rent abatement and damages.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The opinion, even in this concurring/dissenting segment, expressly recognizes that statutes and the State Sanitary Code impose on landlords an obligation, for tenants’ benefit, to comply with minimum habitability standards and that noncompliance affects rent liability. Justice Quirico states that landlords renting dwelling units are obligated to meet Code standards and that tenants may obtain a reduction of rent to the fair value of the premises in light of Code violations, which is a form of rent abatement/damages. Although he would ground the rule more narrowly in the Code rather than a broad implied warranty, he clearly accepts Code compliance as a basic landlord obligation enforceable through rent-based remedies.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt:
“I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards…

…I would state it to be (a) that by renting a dwelling unit a landlord impliedly agrees…that the rented unit complies with such standards… (d) that if the landlord fails in any material respect to comply with the prescribed minimum standards the tenant may…bring an action to recover the excess of the amount paid over and above the fair value of the occupancy of the deficient premises, or (ii) vacate the premises… and as to rent unpaid… the landlord may recover the fair value of such occupancy of the deficient premises.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.proposition: In Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), the Court reiterated that serious or persistent sanitary code violations, when the landlord has notice and fails to correct them, can amount to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord, and it cites prior cases for the principle that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice can violate § 14. Although Al‑Ziab’s specific issue is lead paint, the Court reiterates the broader rule that serious conditions (including sanitary-code-type defects) combined with notice and failure to correct can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 198‑99 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have specifically recognized that rodent infestations and unsanitary conditions can constitute breaches of the warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 198‑99 (1979) (serious code violations, including vermin infestations, justify rent abatement and tenant remedies); Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908‑09 (1987) (sanitary code violations give rise to damages).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses loss of heat and hot water as material breaches of the warranty of habitability and when rent abatement begins, but it does not address rodents, vermin, or unsanitary conditions. The only sanitary‑code reference is general and conceptual; the case does not hold that vermin infestations specifically justify rent abatement or constitute a breach. Thus, citing Berman & Sons for vermin/unsanitary‑condition propositions is inaccurate.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.” (379 Mass. at 201–02).

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908‑09 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts courts have specifically recognized that rodent infestations and unsanitary conditions can constitute breaches of the warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 198‑99 (1979) (serious code violations, including vermin infestations, justify rent abatement and tenant remedies); Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908‑09 (1987) (sanitary code violations give rise to damages).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that numerous State Sanitary Code violations existed in the tenant’s apartment and that a breach of the warranty of habitability occurred, but it does not specifically discuss rodents, vermin, or unsanitary conditions as the basis for that breach. The listed violations include “mice” among many other conditions, and the court’s discussion of damages for breach of warranty is entirely general, focusing on methodology and amount rather than identifying which specific violations (such as rodents) constituted the breach. Thus it is a weak and indirect authority for the specific proposition that rodent infestations and unsanitary conditions can constitute breaches of the warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
“Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property.2 …
…
D. Breach of Warranty of Habitability.
Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability… The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.… There is record support for the amount awarded.”

Footnote 2: “The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788‑89 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code and to maintain the Premises free from rodent infestation, despite notice, constitutes a violation of his statutory duty as landlord and underlies the interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that the landlord’s failure, after notice, to correct serious State Sanitary Code violations including “a serious infestation of vermin” constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment). The court explains that a landlord’s omissions in failing to repair known defects that substantially impair the value of the premises are actionable under § 14, and applies that rule to Cruz Management’s conduct here. That directly supports using such code-violation-based failures to maintain vermin-free premises, despite notice, as the statutory basis for interference with quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 7.raw_text: Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 710, 715‑16 (1989)
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when a landlord’s acts or omissions result in conditions that unreasonably interfere with the tenant’s comfort, repose, and use of the premises, even absent an intent to harass or evict. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 716‑18; Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 710, 715‑16 (1989).
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 7.case_name: Jet Line Services, Inc. v. American Employers Insurance
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Doe v. Boston Housing Auth. at all, but Jet Line Servs., Inc. v. American Employers Ins. Co., a commercial insurance coverage and estoppel case. It does not concern residential tenancies, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or standards for when landlords breach that covenant, and thus cannot support the stated proposition about landlord‑tenant law. The citation to Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 710, 715‑16 (1989) in this context appears to be incorrect or mismatched with the opinion text supplied.
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 404 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: We are now in a position to consider (1) whether Jet Line’s general liability policy covered damage it negligently caused to the Air Force tank, (2) whether, in any event, American is estopped to deny coverage of that damage, and (3) Jet Line’s claims for attorneys’ fees under G. L. c. 93A.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: In addition, G.L. c. 186, § 14 has been interpreted broadly to protect tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s failure to maintain habitable conditions when the landlord has notice and an opportunity to cure. See Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850‑53; Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that G.L. c. 186, § 14 has been interpreted broadly to cover serious interferences resulting from failure to maintain habitable conditions when the landlord has notice and an opportunity to cure. Lowery does interpret § 14 to cover a serious habitability-related interference (failure to provide heat), but it does so without discussing landlord notice, opportunity to cure, or using any ‘broad’ interpretive language about notice-based duties. The case is good authority that lack of heat breaching quiet enjoyment triggers § 14 liability regardless of financial inability, but it does not specifically support the notice-and-opportunity-to-cure aspect of the proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself…, liability will be imposed ‘whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”
